entities.title: Henry, Duke of Cornwall
entities.description: Henry, Duke of Cornwall was the first child of King Henry VIII of England and his first wife, Catherine of Aragon, and though his birth was celebrated as that of the heir apparent, he died within weeks. His death and Henry VIII's failure to produce another surviving male heir with Catherine led to succession and marriage crises that affected the relationship between the English church and Roman Ca

heading: Deaths
txt: Amerigo Vespucci, Italian cartographer and explorer (b. 1454)

entities.title: Amerigo Vespucci
entities.description: Amerigo Vespucci was an Italian-born merchant, explorer, and navigator from the Republic of Florence, from whose name the term "America" is derived. He became a Castillian citizen in 1505.

heading: Deaths
txt: Olivier van Noort, Dutch explorer (b. 1558)

entities.title: Olivier van Noort
entities.description: Olivier van Noort was a Dutch merchant captain and pirate and the first Dutchman to circumnavigate the world.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean Chapelain, French poet and critic (b. 1595)

entities.title: Jean Chapelain
entities.description: Jean Chapelain was a French poet and critic during the Grand Siècle, best known for his role as an organizer and founding member of the Académie française. Chapelain acquired considerable prestige as a literary critic, but his own major work, an epic poem about Joan of Arc called "La Pucelle," (1656) was lampooned by his contemporary Nicolas Boileau-Despréaux.

heading: Deaths
txt: La Voisin, French occultist (b. 1640)

entities.title: La Voisin
entities.description: Catherine Monvoisin, or Montvoisin, née Deshayes, known as "La Voisin", was a French fortune teller, commissioned poisoner, and professional provider of alleged sorcery. She was the head of a network of fortune tellers in Paris providing poison, aphrodisiacs, abortion, purported magical services and the arranging of black masses, with clients among the aristocracy, and became the central figure in

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Le Brun, French painter and theorist (b. 1619)

entities.title: Charles Le Brun
entities.description: Charles Le Brun was a French painter, physiognomist, art theorist, and a director of several art schools of his time. As court painter to Louis XIV, who declared him "the greatest French artist of all time", he was a dominant figure in 17th-century French art and much influenced by Nicolas Poussin.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frederik Ruysch, Dutch physician and anatomist (b. 1638)

entities.title: Frederik Ruysch
entities.description: Frederik Ruysch was a Dutch botanist and anatomist. He is known for developing techniques for preserving anatomical specimens, which he used to create dioramas or scenes incorporating human parts. His anatomical preparations included over 2,000 anatomical, pathological, zoological, and botanical specimens, which were preserved by either drying or embalming. Ruysch is also known for his proof of va

heading: Deaths
txt: Francis Atterbury, English bishop (b. 1663)

entities.title: Francis Atterbury
entities.description: Francis Atterbury was an English man of letters, politician and bishop. A High Church Tory and Jacobite, he gained patronage under Queen Anne, but was mistrusted by the Hanoverian Whig ministries, and banished for communicating with the Old Pretender. He was a noted wit and a gifted preacher.

heading: Deaths
txt: Heshen, Chinese politician (b. 1750)

entities.title: Heshen
entities.description: Heshen (Manchu: ᡥᡝᡧᡝᠨ; Möllendorff: Hešen; Chinese: 和珅; pinyin: Héshēn; Wade–Giles: Ho2-shen1; 1 July 1750 – 22 February 1799) of the Manchu Niohuru clan, was an official of the Qing dynasty favored by the Qianlong Emperor. Born Shanbao (Shan-pao; 善保), his given name was later changed to Heshen. His courtesy name was Zhizhai (Chih-chai; 致齋). He was a member of the Plain Red Banner, and known as th

heading: Deaths
txt: Adam Ferguson, Scottish historian and philosopher (b. 1723)

entities.title: Adam Ferguson
entities.description: Adam Ferguson, FRSE, also known as Ferguson of Raith, was a Scottish philosopher and historian of the Scottish Enlightenment.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot, French painter and illustrator (b. 1796)

entities.title: Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot
entities.description: Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot was a French landscape and portrait painter as well as a printmaker in etching. He is a pivotal figure in landscape painting and his vast output simultaneously references the Neo-Classical tradition and anticipates the plein-air innovations of Impressionism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Lyell, Scottish-English geologist and lawyer (b. 1797)

heading: Deaths
txt: Anna Kingsford, English physician and activist (b. 1846)

entities.title: Anna Kingsford
entities.description: Anna Kingsford, was an English anti-vivisectionist, vegetarian and women's rights campaigner.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Jacob Astor III, American businessman and philanthropist (b. 1822)

entities.title: John Jacob Astor III
entities.description: John Jacob Astor III was an American financier, philanthropist and a soldier during the American Civil War. He was a prominent member of the Astor family, becoming the wealthiest member in his generation and the founder of the English branch of the family.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Bloch, Danish painter and academic (b. 1834)

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Blondin, French tightrope walker and acrobat (b. 1824)

entities.title: Charles Blondin
entities.description: Charles Blondin was a French tightrope walker and acrobat. He toured the United States and was known for crossing the 1,100 ft (340 m) Niagara Gorge on a tightrope.

heading: Deaths
txt: Heungseon Daewongun, Korean king (b. 1820)

entities.title: Heungseon Daewongun
entities.description: Heungseon Daewongun, also known as the Daewongun, Guktaegong or formally Heungseon Heonui Daewonwang and also known to contemporary western diplomats as Prince Gung, was the title of Yi Ha-eung, regent of Joseon during the minority of Emperor Gojong in the 1860s and until his death a key political figure of late Joseon Korea.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hugo Wolf, Austrian composer (b. 1860)

entities.title: Hugo Wolf
entities.description: Hugo Philipp Jacob Wolf was an Austrian composer of Slovene origin, particularly noted for his art songs, or Lieder. He brought to this form a concentrated expressive intensity which was unique in late Romantic music, somewhat related to that of the Second Viennese School in concision but diverging greatly in technique.

heading: Deaths
txt: Leslie Stephen, English historian, author, and critic (b. 1832)

entities.title: Leslie Stephen
entities.description: Sir Leslie Stephen was an English author, critic, historian, biographer, and mountaineer, and father of Virginia Woolf and Vanessa Bell.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ferdinand de Saussure, Swiss linguist and author (b. 1857)

entities.title: Ferdinand de Saussure
entities.description: Ferdinand de Saussure was a Swiss linguist, semiotician and philosopher. His ideas laid a foundation for many significant developments in both linguistics and semiotics in the 20th century. He is widely considered one of the founders of 20th-century linguistics and one of two major founders of semiotics, or semiology, as Saussure called it.

heading: Deaths
txt: Francisco I. Madero, Mexican president and author (b. 1873)

heading: Deaths
txt: Théophile Delcassé, French politician, French Minister of Foreign Affairs (b. 1852)

entities.title: Théophile Delcassé
entities.description: Théophile Delcassé was a French statesman and foreign minister 1898–1905. He is best known for his hatred of Germany and efforts to secure alliances with Russia and Great Britain that became the Entente Cordiale. He belonged to Radical party and was a protege of Léon Gambetta.

entities.title: Minister of Foreign Affairs (France)
entities.description: The Ministry for Europe and Foreign Affairs is the ministry of the Government of France that handles France's foreign relations. Since 1855, its headquarters have been located at 37 Quai d'Orsay, close to the National Assembly. The term Quai d'Orsay is often used as a metonym for the ministry. Its cabinet minister, the Minister for Europe and Foreign Affairs is responsible for the foreign relation

heading: Deaths
txt: Antonio Machado, Spanish-French poet and author (b. 1875)

entities.title: Antonio Machado
entities.description: Antonio Cipriano José María y Francisco de Santa Ana Machado y Ruiz, known as Antonio Machado, was a Spanish poet and one of the leading figures of the Spanish literary movement known as the Generation of '98. His work, initially modernist, evolved towards an intimate form of symbolism with romantic traits. He gradually developed a style characterised by both an engagement with humanity on one sid

heading: Deaths
txt: Stefan Zweig, Austrian journalist, author, and playwright (b. 1881)

entities.title: Stefan Zweig
entities.description: Stefan Zweig was an Austrian novelist, playwright, journalist and biographer. At the height of his literary career, in the 1920s and 1930s, he was one of the most widely translated and most popular writers in the world.

heading: Deaths
txt: Christoph Probst, German activist (b. 1919)

entities.title: Christoph Probst
entities.description: Christoph Ananda Probst was a German student of medicine and member of the White Rose resistance group.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hans Scholl, German activist (b. 1918)

heading: Deaths
txt: Sophie Scholl, German activist (b. 1921)

heading: Deaths
txt: Kasturba Gandhi, Indian activist (b. 1869)

entities.title: Kasturba Gandhi
entities.description: Kasturbai "Kasturba" Mohandas Gandhi (listen   born Kasturbai Gokuldas Kapadia on was an Indian political activist. She married Mohandas Gandhi in 1883. In association with her husband and son, she was involved in the Indian independence movement in British-ruled India. She was very influenced by her husband Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, a.k.a. Mahatma Gandhi.

heading: Deaths
txt: Osip Brik, Russian avant garde writer and literary critic (b. 1888)

entities.title: Osip Brik
entities.description: Osip Maksimovich Brik, was a Russian avant garde writer and literary critic, who was one of the most important members of the Russian formalist school, though he also identified himself as one of the Futurists.

heading: Deaths
txt: Abul Kalam Azad, Indian scholar and politician, Indian Minister of Education (b. 1888)

entities.title: Abul Kalam Azad
entities.description: Abul Kalam Ghulam Muhiyuddin Ahmed bin Khairuddin Al-Hussaini Azad pronunciation (help·info) was an Indian scholar, Islamic theologian, independence activist, and a senior leader of the Indian National Congress during the Indian independence movement. Following India's independence, he became the First Minister of Education in the Indian government. He is commonly remembered as Maulana Azad; the w

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul-Émile Borduas, Canadian-French painter and critic (b. 1905)

entities.title: Paul-Émile Borduas
entities.description: Paul-Émile Borduas was a Québecois artist known for his abstract paintings. He was the leader of the avant-garde Automatiste movement and the chief author of the Refus Global manifesto of 1948. Borduas had a profound impact on the development of the arts and of thought, both in the province of Quebec and in Canada.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nick LaRocca, American trumpet player and composer (b. 1889)

entities.title: Nick LaRocca
entities.description: Dominic James "Nick" LaRocca, was an American early jazz cornetist and trumpeter and the leader of the Original Dixieland Jass Band. He is the composer of one of the most recorded jazz classics of all-time, "Tiger Rag". He was part of what is generally regarded as the first recorded jazz band, a band which recorded and released the first jazz recording, "Livery Stable Blues" in 1917.

heading: Deaths
txt: Felix Frankfurter, Austrian-American lawyer and jurist (b. 1882)

entities.title: Felix Frankfurter
entities.description: Felix Frankfurter was an American lawyer, professor, and jurist who served as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. Frankfurter served on the Supreme Court from 1939 to 1962 and was a noted advocate of judicial restraint in the judgments of the Court.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frédéric Mariotti, French actor (b. 1883)

entities.title: Frédéric Mariotti
entities.description: Frédéric Mariotti was a French stage and film actor whose career spanned more than four decades through the early silent film era into the early 1950s.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Jacques Bertrand, Canadian lawyer and politician, 21st Premier of Quebec (b. 1916)

entities.title: Jean-Jacques Bertrand
entities.description: Jean-Jacques Bertrand was the 21st Premier of Quebec, Canada, from October 2, 1968, to May 12, 1970. He led the Union Nationale party.

entities.title: List of Quebec premiers
entities.description: This is a list of the premiers of the province of Quebec, Canada, since Confederation in 1867. Quebec uses a unicameral Westminster-style parliamentary government, in which the premier is the leader of the party that controls the most seats in the National Assembly. The premier, sometimes called the prime minister, is Quebec's head of government, while the Queen of Canada is its head of state and

heading: Deaths
txt: Elizabeth Bowen, Anglo-Irish author (b. 1899)

heading: Deaths
txt: Katina Paxinou, Greek actress (b. 1900)

heading: Deaths
txt: Winthrop Rockefeller, American colonel and politician, 37th Governor of Arkansas (b. 1912)

entities.title: Governor of Arkansas
entities.description: The Governor of Arkansas is the head of government of the U.S. state of Arkansas. The Governor is the head of the executive branch of the Arkansas government and is charged with enforcing state laws. They have the power to either approve or veto bills passed by the Arkansas General Assembly, to convene the legislature, and to grant pardons, except in cases of treason and impeachment.

heading: Deaths
txt: Angela Baddeley, English actress (b. 1904)

entities.title: Angela Baddeley
entities.description: Angela Baddeley, CBE was an English stage and television actress, best-remembered for her role as household cook Mrs. Bridges in the period drama Upstairs, Downstairs. Her stage career lasted more than six decades.

heading: Deaths
txt: Florence Ballard, American singer (b. 1943)

heading: Deaths
txt: Oskar Kokoschka, Austrian painter, poet and playwright (b. 1886)

entities.title: Oskar Kokoschka
entities.description: Oskar Kokoschka was an Austrian artist, poet, playwright, and teacher best known for his intense expressionistic portraits and landscapes, as well as his theories on vision that influenced the Viennese Expressionist movement.

heading: Deaths
txt: Josh Malihabadi, Indian-Pakistani poet and author (b. 1898)

entities.title: Josh Malihabadi
entities.description: Josh Malihabadi popularly known as Shayar-e-Inqalab is regarded as one of the finest Urdu poets of the era of British India. Known for his liberal values and challenging the established order, he wrote over 100,000 couplets and more than 1,000 rubaiyat in his lifetime. His wrote Yaadon ki Barat, his autobiography which is noted for its frank and candid style. The first Prime Minister of India, Jaw

heading: Deaths
txt: Adrian Boult, English conductor (b. 1889)

entities.title: Adrian Boult
entities.description: Sir Adrian Cedric Boult, CH was an English conductor. Brought up in a prosperous mercantile family, he followed musical studies in England and at Leipzig, Germany, with early conducting work in London for the Royal Opera House and Sergei Diaghilev's ballet company. His first prominent post was conductor of the City of Birmingham Orchestra in 1924. When the British Broadcasting Corporation appointe

heading: Deaths
txt: Romain Maes, Belgian cyclist (b. 1913)

heading: Deaths
txt: Salvador Espriu, Spanish author, poet, and playwright (b. 1913)

entities.title: Salvador Espriu
entities.description: Salvador Espriu i Castelló was a Catalan poet who wrote most of his works in Catalan.

heading: Deaths
txt: Efrem Zimbalist, Russian violinist, composer, and conductor (b. 1889)

heading: Deaths
txt: John Donnelly, Australian rugby league player (b. 1955)

entities.title: John Donnelly (rugby league)
entities.description: John "Dallas" Donnelly was an Australian professional rugby league footballer who played in the 1970s and 1980s. An Australian Kangaroos and New South Wales Blues representative, he played for Western Suburbs between 1975 and 1984 in the New South Wales Rugby League premiership.

heading: Deaths
txt: David Susskind, American talk show host and producer (b. 1920)

entities.title: David Susskind
entities.description: David Howard Susskind was an American producer of TV, movies, and stage plays and also a TV talk show host. His talk shows were innovative in the genre and addressed timely, controversial topics beyond the scope of others of the day.

heading: Deaths
txt: Andy Warhol, American painter and photographer (b. 1928)

heading: Deaths
txt: Markos Vafiadis, Greek general and politician (b. 1906)

entities.title: Markos Vafiadis
entities.description: Markos Vafeiadis was a leading figure of the Communist Party of Greece (KKE) during the Greek Resistance and the Greek Civil War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Papa John Creach, American violinist (b. 1917)

entities.title: Papa John Creach
entities.description: John Henry Creach, better known as Papa John Creach, was an American blues violinist, who also played classical, jazz, R&B, pop and acid rock music. Early in his career, he performed as a journeyman musician with Louis Armstrong, Fats Waller, Stuff Smith, Charlie Christian, Big Joe Turner, T-Bone Walker, Nat King Cole and Roy Milton.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ed Flanders, American actor (b. 1934)

entities.title: Ed Flanders
entities.description: Edward Paul Flanders was an American actor. He is best known for playing Dr. Donald Westphall in the medical drama series St. Elsewhere (1982–1988). Flanders was nominated for eight Primetime Emmys and won three times in 1976, 1977, and 1983.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Aiuppa, American gangster (b. 1907)

entities.title: Joseph Aiuppa
entities.description: Joseph John Aiuppa, also known as "Joey O'Brien" and "Joey Doves", was a Chicago mobster who became a leader of the Chicago Outfit from 1971 until his skimming conviction in 1986.

heading: Deaths
txt: Abraham A. Ribicoff, American lawyer and politician, 4th United States Secretary of Health and Human Services (b. 1910)

entities.title: Abraham A. Ribicoff
entities.description: Abraham Alexander Ribicoff was an American Democratic Party politician from the state of Connecticut. He represented Connecticut in the United States House of Representatives and Senate and was the 80th Governor of Connecticut and Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare in President John F. Kennedy's cabinet. He was Connecticut's first and to date only Jewish governor.

entities.title: United States Secretary of Health and Human Services
entities.description: The United States secretary of health and human services is the head of the United States Department of Health and Human Services, and serves as the principal advisor to the president of the United States on all health matters. The secretary is a member of the United States Cabinet. The office was formerly Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare. In 1980, the Department of Health, Education, a

heading: Deaths
txt: William Bronk, American poet and academic (b. 1918)

entities.title: William Bronk
entities.description: William Bronk was an American poet. For his book, Life Supports (1981), he won the National Book Award for Poetry.

heading: Deaths
txt: Menno Oosting, Dutch tennis player (b. 1964)

heading: Deaths
txt: Roden Cutler, Australian lieutenant and politician, 32nd Governor of New South Wales (b. 1916)

entities.title: Roden Cutler
entities.description: Sir Arthur Roden Cutler,, known as Sir Roden Cutler, was an Australian diplomat, the longest serving Governor of New South Wales and a recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest award for gallantry "in the face of the enemy" that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth armed forces.

entities.title: Governor of New South Wales
entities.description: The Governor of New South Wales is the viceregal representative of the Australian monarch, Queen Elizabeth II, in the state of New South Wales. In an analogous way to the Governor-General of Australia at the national level, the Governors of the Australian states perform constitutional and ceremonial functions at the state level. entities.title: UNITA
entities.description: The National Union for the Total Independence of Angola is the second-largest political party in Angola. Founded in 1966, UNITA fought alongside the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) in the Angolan War for Independence (1961–1975) and then against the MPLA in the ensuing civil war (1975–2002). The war was one of the most prominent Cold War proxy wars, with UNITA receiving milita

heading: Deaths
txt: Andy Seminick, American baseball player, coach, and manager (b. 1920)

entities.title: Andy Seminick
entities.description: Andrew Wasal Seminick was an American professional baseball player. He played in Major League Baseball as a catcher for the Philadelphia Phillies between 1943 and 1951, and the Cincinnati Reds/Redlegs from 1952 through part of 1955, when he rejoined the Phillies for the rest of his career until his release at the end of the 1957 season. Seminick was an integral part of the 1950 "Whiz Kids" Phillie

heading: Deaths
txt: Lee Eun-ju, South Korean actress and singer (b. 1980)

entities.title: Lee Eun-ju
entities.description: Lee Eun-ju was a South Korean actress. She was the star of hit films including Taegukgi and The Scarlet Letter. She died by suicide at age 24.

heading: Deaths
txt: Simone Simon, French actress (b. 1910)

heading: Deaths
txt: S. Rajaratnam, Singaporean politician, 1st Senior Minister of Singapore (b. 1915)

entities.title: S. Rajaratnam
entities.description: Sinnathamby Rajaratnam, DUT ,, was a Deputy Prime Minister of Singapore from 1980–85. He took office when former deputy prime minister Goh Keng Swee, a long-serving Minister, member of the Cabinet from 1959–88, and short story writer, stepped down from the position. He was one of the pioneer leaders of independent Singapore as it achieved self-government in 1959 and later independence in 1965. He

entities.title: Senior Minister
entities.description: The Senior Minister is a political office in the Cabinet of Singapore. Previous holders of this office have served as either the Prime Minister or as the former Deputy Prime Minister. heading: Deaths
txt: George Jellicoe, 2nd Earl Jellicoe, English politician, Leader of the House of Lords (b. 1918)

entities.title: George Jellicoe, 2nd Earl Jellicoe
entities.description: George Patrick John Rushworth Jellicoe, 2nd Earl Jellicoe, Baron Jellicoe of Southampton, was a British politician, diplomat and businessman.

entities.title: Leader of the House of Lords
entities.description: The Leader of the House of Lords is a member of the Cabinet of the United Kingdom who is responsible for arranging government business in the House of Lords. The post is also the leader of the majority party in the House of Lords who acts as the government party chairperson in the house. txt: Dennis Johnson, American basketball player and coach (b. 1954)

heading: Deaths
txt: Sukhbir, Indian author and poet (b. 1925)

entities.title: Sukhbir (writer)
entities.description: Sukhbir, alias Balbir Singh, was a Punjabi novelist, short-story writer, poet and essayist. He wrote and published for fifty years. He wrote seven novels, 11 short story collections, and five poetry collections, and made many translations of world literature, essays, letters and book reviews.

entities.description: Charlotte Dawson was a New Zealand–Australian television personality. She was known in New Zealand for her roles as host of Getaway, and in Australia as a host on The Contender Australia and as a judge on Australia's Next Top Model. In 2014, her death by suicide attracted Australian-wide news coverage.

heading: Deaths
txt: Yolande Fox, American model and singer, Miss America 1951 (b. 1928)

entities.description: Yolande Margaret Betbeze Fox was an American singer and beauty pageant titleholder who was crowned Miss America 1951.

entities.title: Miss America
entities.description: Miss America is an annual competition that is open to women from the United States between the ages of 17 and 25. heading: Deaths
txt: Brody Stevens, American comedian and actor (b. 1970)

entities.title: Brody Stevens
entities.description: Steven James Brody, known professionally as Brody Stevens, was an American stand-up comedian and actor. He starred in the Comedy Central reality series Brody Stevens: Enjoy It!, and was known for appearances on Chelsea Lately and other comedy shows as well as small roles in films such as The Hangover (2009) and Due Date (2010).

heading: Deaths
txt: Morgan Woodward, American actor (b. 1925)

entities.description: Lawrence Monsanto Ferlinghetti was an American poet, painter, social activist, and the co-founder of City Lights Booksellers & Publishers. He was the author of poetry, translations, fiction, theatre, art criticism, and film narration.
